snippet.textDisplay: I'm impatiently waiting to get my hands on a Switch to play this (I know the Wii U version is completely OK, but it's not like I don't already have tons of games to play), and with such a historically high reception, I'm beyond excited. I went to a friend's house last week and he showed a couple parts and the size of the world, how dense it is and the number of things you can do is mind boggling. He also showed me a few minutes of the Hyrule Castle as he was about to go fight Ganon and hearing this theme was amazing. Honestly, this raises a new bar for Open World games and I wonder how other developers will react to prevent their own games in the genre from feeling bland. I look forward to playing it and give it my full thoughts here afterwards.
snippet.textOriginal: I'm impatiently waiting to get my hands on a Switch to play this (I know the Wii U version is completely OK, but it's not like I don't already have tons of games to play), and with such a historically high reception, I'm beyond excited. He also showed me a few minutes of the Hyrule Castle as he was about to go fight Ganon and hearing this theme was amazing. Honestly, this raises a new bar for Open World games and I wonder how other developers will react to prevent their own games in the genre from feeling bland. I look forward to playing it and give it my full thoughts here afterwards.

snippet.textDisplay:
I got it for the Wii U, good times. I'd just get it for the Wii U if you have one, but yeah it's your call if you really feel like you have to wait. I wouldn't even consider getting a Switch until Christmas. I wound up actually loving the WIi U after all when I randomly bought it one summer sale.  There just isn't a lot on the Switch at all now. 

I don't really get that soft launch entirely though I'd like to see the Switch do well as I feel bad for the Wii U in some aspects. Nintendo gimped themselves relying too much on the tablet gimmick, but I still like the Wii U a lot anyways (never owning a Wii helps my case for it too).

snippet.textDisplay: Speaking of the overworld: Monoltih Soft (known for Xenoblade) helped Nintendo with BotW. Which means that every piece of the overworld is made by hand, and not generated biomes like many other open world games (like Skyrim). The attention to details is overwhelming.
snippet.textOriginal: Speaking of the overworld: Monoltih Soft (known for Xenoblade) helped Nintendo with BotW. Which means that every piece of the overworld is made by hand, and not generated biomes like many other open world games (like Skyrim). The attention to details is overwhelming.

snippet.textDisplay: I believe everyone who plays Breath of the Wild will have complaints (both minor and major ones), but most of them arises from the way you play it. BotW is not only completely non-linear, but it also gives the player a lot of freedom in their own play style. I know a lot of people who played it, and everyone played it in different ways. One did a lot of sidequests, one rushed directly to dungeons, one did not use potions and food so that battles got harder, etc. I feel like BotW will revolutionize the open world genre. Its level design is stellar to say the least, far beyond most games. If you play it, have fun! It really is a good game.
snippet.textOriginal: I believe everyone who plays Breath of the Wild will have complaints (both minor and major ones), but most of them arises from the way you play it. BotW is not only completely non-linear, but it also gives the player a lot of freedom in their own play style. I know a lot of people who played it, and everyone played it in different ways. One did a lot of sidequests, one rushed directly to dungeons, one did not use potions and food so that battles got harder, etc. I feel like BotW will revolutionize the open world genre. Its level design is stellar to say the least, far beyond most games. If you play it, have fun! It really is a good game.

snippet.textDisplay: This song is made 1000 times more impactful if you hear it for the first time by going straight to the castle from the plateau. The music only adds to that feeling of being over your head.

snippet.textDisplay: You'd put Breath of the Wild 10th of the main Zelda games? There are only 9 main console games (the original, Zelda II, A Link to the Past, Ocarina of Time, Majora's Mask, Wind Waker, Twilight Princess, Skyward Sword, Breath of the Wild). I'm curious what your top 10 list is, because it seems like you're being contrary for attention.

snippet.textDisplay: I disagree Destati. BotW shares many aspects of the Zelda series (excellent world building, weird npcs, etc.), and it shares more aspects with the NES Zelda than any other Zelda game out there. Its overworld is a silent beauty. Decaying ruins, little civilization, and a lot of wild animals. I did not mean it as a bad thing when I said that BotW builds atmosphere using sound effects instead of music. Unlike for example Dark Souls, which does the same thing, I would say that BotW really nailed this technique.
snippet.textOriginal: I disagree Destati. BotW shares many aspects of the Zelda series (excellent world building, weird npcs, etc.), and it shares more aspects with the NES Zelda than any other Zelda game out there. Its overworld is a silent beauty. Decaying ruins, little civilization, and a lot of wild animals. I did not mean it as a bad thing when I said that BotW builds atmosphere using sound effects instead of music. Unlike for example Dark Souls, which does the same thing, I would say that BotW really nailed this technique.

snippet.textDisplay: My playthrough is winding down a bit at 120 hours. There are a few sidequests and shrines left, and I already look at a lot of places of Hyrule and thinking "Man, I wish I could explore this for the first time again." That's how you know you're playing an incredible game. It's not perfect, I have a few problems with it, but it's one of the best games I've played in a long time, and I'm really excited to see what's next for the franchise.
snippet.textOriginal: My playthrough is winding down a bit at 120 hours. There are a few sidequests and shrines left, and I already look at a lot of places of Hyrule and thinking "Man, I wish I could explore this for the first time again." That's how you know you're playing an incredible game. It's not perfect, I have a few problems with it, but it's one of the best games I've played in a long time, and I'm really excited to see what's next for the franchise.

snippet.textDisplay:
To be honest, I love Breath of the Wild's music. Sure, it's not as memorable as the previous titles but there is something special about that music that feels "Zelda-ish" with that atmosphere. Maybe it's because of this atmosphere that I still remember of the music. I feel an epic soundtrack would break that universe and I could be kinda annoyed by that.
But I understand what you are saying. There's so much memorable music in the saga that BotW's music sounds odd or unusual.
snippet.textOriginal:
To be honest, I love Breath of the Wild's music. Sure, it's not as memorable as the previous titles but there is something special about that music that feels "Zelda-ish" with that atmosphere. Maybe it's because of this atmosphere that I still remember of the music. I feel an epic soundtrack would break that universe and I could be kinda annoyed by that.
But I understand what you are saying. There's so much memorable music in the saga that BotW's music sounds odd or unusual.

snippet.textDisplay: I don't think it was the soundtrack itself that was bad, but the lack of one. There wasn't a lot of music in the game, but in the sparse areas that had music, they were fantastic. This track, Calamity Ganon battle, Rito Village, Gerudo City, Kakariko, the Divine Beast Battles, Blight battles, Sandworm battle, and Horse-Night theme are just a few themes that sounded amazing. It's a shame that the developers decided to go with a more ambient soundtrack then a full blown orchestral arrangement like previous games.
snippet.textOriginal: I don't think it was the soundtrack itself that was bad, but the lack of one. There wasn't a lot of music in the game, but in the sparse areas that had music, they were fantastic. This track, Calamity Ganon battle, Rito Village, Gerudo City, Kakariko, the Divine Beast Battles, Blight battles, Sandworm battle, and Horse-Night theme are just a few themes that sounded amazing. It's a shame that the developers decided to go with a more ambient soundtrack then a full blown orchestral arrangement like previous games.

snippet.textDisplay:
I imagine BotW's OST was designed to be more ambient. Since you'll be travelling a lot in the overworld, they probably wanted to avoid the music from being repetitive and distract you from taking in the glorious environments surrounding you. The more standout tracks were given to all the towns (since you won't stay in them too long, they wrote the songs to be more impressive and therefore memorable, before leaving them), as well as the battles to increase the tension/drama of the action.

If they made a standout track like OoT's Hyrule Field and put it on repeat in BotW's overworld, it would probably get really old fast (despite how good it is.)
snippet.textOriginal:
I imagine BotW's OST was designed to be more ambient. Since you'll be travelling a lot in the overworld, they probably wanted to avoid the music from being repetitive and distract you from taking in the glorious environments surrounding you. The more standout tracks were given to all the towns (since you won't stay in them too long, they wrote the songs to be more impressive and therefore memorable, before leaving them), as well as the battles to increase the tension/drama of the action.

If they made a standout track like OoT's Hyrule Field and put it on repeat in BotW's overworld, it would probably get really old fast (despite how good it is.)
